content: The "Swine Producers Market Loss Assistance Act of 1999" includes sections on short title, table of contents, findings and purposes, definitions, market loss assistance, payment amounts, relationship to other payments, emergency requirements, livestock market reporting, and regulations. The findings of the "Swine Producers Market Loss Assistance Act of 1999" highlight the adverse effects of changes in marketing relationships and industry concentration on swine producers, impacting prices and slaughter capacity in the United States. The swine market price crisis in the United States from October 1, 1998, to December 31, 1998, was caused by a 10% increase in swine available for slaughter, an 8% decrease in packer slaughter capacity compared to the previous year, and a 37% increase in Canadian swine imports. The fourth quarter of 1998 saw the lowest live swine prices in the US spot market for the 20th century, with a 37% decrease compared to 1932. Swine producers faced a $2.6 billion reduction in equity capital investment value in 1998. In 1998, swine producers received only $0.22 of the consumer pork dollar, marking a significant decrease from previous years. Despite stable retail prices, pork consumption increased by seven percent, making it the only meat protein with a rise in per capita consumption that year. In 1998, pork consumption increased by seven percent, reflecting a net per capita consumption increase. The purpose of this Act is to compensate swine producers for losses incurred in the fourth quarter of 1998 due to adverse economic factors and government failures in pursuing foreign trade opportunities. The Act aims to compensate swine producers for losses in 1998 due to adverse economic factors and missed trade opportunities. The Act aims to compensate swine producers for losses in 1998 due to adverse economic factors and missed trade opportunities. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "swine" refers to porcine animals raised for feeder pigs or slaughter in the United States during the crisis period from October 1, 1998, to December 31, 1998. "Swine producer" is defined as a person in the US who produced swine during this period. "Packer" is defined as per the Packers and Stockyards Act, 1921. "Feeder pig" refers to young swine. The term "feeder pig" in the Packers and Stockyards Act, 1921 refers to young swine sold for further feeding for over one month during the crisis period. The term "swine operation" defines a person or group raising swine in the United States during this period. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. SEC. 4. MARKET LOSS ASSISTANCE. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide financial assistance to swine producers to offset market losses incurred during the crisis period. Eligibility for payments requires maintaining a swine operation and marketing swine for slaughter during the crisis period. Certain swine producers are ineligible for assistance. Certain swine producers are ineligible for financial assistance under this Act if they are affiliated with publicly owned packers. The Secretary will limit assistance to eligible swine producers through an application process. The Act limits assistance to eligible swine producers through an application process. Producers must submit required information to the Secretary for eligibility determination. SEC. 5. PAYMENT AMOUNTS AND PAYMENT LIMITATIONS. Assistance under this Act will be distributed fairly and equitably to swine producers who have incurred losses. The maximum payment per slaughter-weight swine is $25.00, and for feeder pigs, it is $9.00 per pig marketed during the crisis period. During the crisis period, payments to swine producers will not exceed $9.00 per feeder pig marketed. Payments to swine operation producers will be calculated by multiplying the number of eligible swine marketed and slaughtered by $25.00, and adding the number of eligible feeder pigs, if any. During the crisis period, payments to swine producers are calculated by multiplying the number of eligible swine marketed and slaughtered by $25.00, adding the number of eligible feeder pigs multiplied by $9.00, and deducting payments received in the program. Payment limitations are set at $50,000 per swine operation for a swine producer. SEC. 6. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER PAYMENTS. Assistance provided under this Act is in addition to assistance, payments, or loans obtained under other agricultural programs. Payments received for the 1998 crop year under various agricultural programs including the noninsured crop assistance program, crop insurance indemnities, and emergency loans. Assistance and payments were also made to swine producers under the Small Hog Operation Program of the Department of Agriculture. Payments made to swine producers under the Small Hog Operation Program of the Department of Agriculture, announced on January 8, 1999, will be deducted from payments made under this Act using funds from section 32 of the Act of August 24, 1935. SEC. 7 of the Act designates funds as an emergency requirement and authorizes the use of the Commodity Credit Corporation. SEC. 8 mandates livestock market reporting. SEC. 8 mandates livestock market reporting under the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946. In this section, livestock is defined as cattle, sheep, and swine, whether alive or dead. Livestock product refers to any product derived from livestock. A packer is defined as a person involved in buying livestock for slaughter or processing livestock products. The term 'prices, volume, and terms of sale' in the context of livestock commerce includes factors like base price, premiums, discounts, pricing systems, and quality characteristics. The Secretary of Agriculture defines discount price factors, formula-based pricing systems, and quality characteristics for packers buying cattle, sheep, or swine. Mandatory reporting is required for packers with more than five percent daily volume in livestock commerce. The Secretary mandates reporting for packers handling over five percent of livestock commerce, requiring information on prices, volume, and terms of sale. The Secretary requires packers handling over five percent of livestock commerce to provide information on prices, volume, and terms of sale for domestic and imported livestock and products by the next business day. The Secretary mandates packers handling over five percent of livestock commerce to report pricing and sales information by the next business day. Noncompliance is unlawful, and the Secretary can verify the accuracy of the information and impose penalties if necessary. The Secretary can issue a cease and desist order and impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for each violation if a packer is found to be violating regulations regarding livestock pricing and sales information. The Secretary can impose a civil penalty on a packer for violations related to livestock pricing and sales information, considering factors like gravity of the offense and business size. If the penalty is not appealed or upheld, the case may be referred to the attorney general. The Secretary can impose civil penalties on packers for violations related to livestock pricing and sales information. If the packer fails to pay the penalty, the matter may be referred to the Attorney General for recovery in a civil action. The Secretary also encourages voluntary reporting by packers not subject to mandatory reporting requirements. The Secretary must make information received under this section available to the public in a timely manner while ensuring the identities of parties involved in transactions and packers submitting reports are not disclosed. The reporting requirement established by subsection (b) shall expire at the end of the three-year period beginning on the date of the enactment of this section, with provisions to protect confidentiality and proprietary business information. The pilot price reporting investigation under Section 416 of the Packers and Stockyards Act, 1921 is repealed. SEC. 9. REGULATIONS. The Secretary and the Commodity Credit Corporation must issue regulations promptly after the enactment of the Act to implement it. The regulations will address misrepresentations, appeals, and entitlement to benefits without the need for notice and comment provisions. The Secretary and the Commodity Credit Corporation must issue regulations promptly after the enactment of the Act to implement it, addressing misrepresentations, appeals, and entitlement to benefits by estates, trusts, and minors. The regulations shall be issued without following certain provisions related to notice and comment, public participation, and the Paperwork Reduction Act. The Secretary must issue regulations promptly after the Act's enactment to implement it, without following certain provisions related to notice and comment, public participation, and the Paperwork Reduction Act.
